content.webTitle: Shane Warne: 'I’m just a guy going to a bar trying to unwind'

fields.headline: Shane Warne: 'I’m just a guy going to a bar trying to unwind'
fields.bodyText: Hi Shane. So you’re out in New York City for the Cricket All-Stars tour to promote the game in the US. Is it nice to be able to walk down the street without getting mobbed? I do get mobbed! We just walked out of a building and there were about 10 people that wanted selfies. Without trying to pump myself and Sachin [Tendulkar] up, I think we’ve given a good account of ourselves as ambassadors for the sport. People have realised that and said, “hang on, these guys actually are a bit of a big deal and people do like them”. There’s so much awareness here: we’re on the front of the New York Times! And now you’re chatting to Small Talk! Yep. How exciting. Do you think of yourself as the David Beckham of cricket? I don’t see myself as David Beckham. But we’ve got Murali, [Mahela] Jayawardene, [Kumar] Sangakkara, Curtly Ambrose, Courtney Walsh, Brian Lara, [VVS] Laxman, [Sourav] Ganguly, [Rahul] Dravid, [Virender] Sehwag, Tendulkar, [Ricky] Ponting, [Glenn] McGrath, [Matthew] Hayden, [Andrew] Symonds, myself, Wasim Akram, Shoaib Akhtar all out here, so we’re trying to have a similar impact on cricket as David had on soccer in the US. Graeme Swann is out with you as well, but where are the rest of the English boys? They’re all doing the punditry thing right now aren’t they. Who has got the weakest banter at Sky? Nasser [Hussain]. I can wind him up very easily, on the pitch or in the commentary box. I remember when he was captain of England and I was captain of Australia at an ODI in Sydney. England only needed 20 or 30 with seven wickets in hand and they were cruising. I started sledging Nasser from cover and he got hooked, it was like Jaws grabbing on the end of a line. I brought myself on the next over and he ran down the wicket trying to hit me for six and got out stumped. McGrath and I cleaned up the rest and we won from nowhere. I like to remind him of that – in a rain delay I’ll try and get the producer to put that game on. Who is your best pal in the All-Stars? Obviously I’m pretty close with all the Australian guys. I’ve probably spent a lot of time with Sachin and Brian Lara. I talk about the game with Sachin and the matches we’ve played in the past and Brian is good fun to have a beer with and a bit of a laugh afterwards. More of a buddy to sit in a nice cool bar with. You’re a single man, do you get chatted up in the NYC bars? I’m just a guy going to a bar trying to unwind. You revealed earlier this year that you’re on Tinder. Have you been using that in the US? I used it when I landed at the airport, but the Wi-Fi wasn’t working properly. I haven’t had a chance to do anything or check it out, but I’ll see how the time goes. Small Talk isn’t very good at dating. Not enough chit-chat apparently. Any tips? I don’t live on it, it’s just a bit of fun. You coached and gave a few pointers to [England spin bowler] Adil Rashid recently. How did that go? He’s a work in progress. He’s going to get better with time, but still a very good bowler right now. He’s not quite at the level of Yasir Shah though – out of all the people that I’ve ever coached or had a session with, he’s got the best leg break I’ve ever seen. He’s messaging me every day asking ‘what else can you teach me?’ I was his hero, he had posters of me on his wall, so it’s nice to work with Yasir. But I hope that the tips I’ve given to Rashid will help him too. If I can help both of them, I’m more than happy. The Guardian did a recent poll asking readers if you were the most famous Australian alive. Many said yes. Who is your favourite Aussie? I feel very flattered to be considered that famous! Kylie Minogue or Barry Humphries, aka Dame Edna Everage, are my favourites. Barry’s Sir Les Patterson is amazing, and Kylie … well she’s just Kylie. This year you unveiled a mural in your home with a few of your favourite celebrities and friends painted on it. Oh yeah, The Ultimate Party it’s called. Anthony Hopkins is cooking up some brains on the barbecue, Frank Sinatra is entertaining the whole crowd, Elvis is looking cool. I’m just chilling in the corner with Bruce Springsteen. The Boss! Mr USA! Get him down to Cricket All-Stars, he could bowl the first ball! Well, we’ve got a few surprises up our sleeves over who is going to be tossing the coin. All I’ll say is that we’re big fans of John McEnroe. You big tease. Of the people still alive, do you know everybody in the painting? I’ve met a few of those guys, Chris Martin from Coldplay is one of my closest friends. There’s a few others that aren’t on there as well: Ed Sheeran has become a good mate of mine, and I’m very lucky to have known Elton John for over 20 years. What is your karaoke song? It’s a really bad one and I only sing it when I’m particularly drunk: Paradise by the Dashboard Light by Meat Loaf. I know every little bit of it, too. Can you sing it to Small Talk now? No. Small Talk hopes there’s some footage [Small Talk furiously Googles but can only find this tweet] out there somewhere. Nobody will ever see the footage. Last year, you said you were writing a song? What became of that? It’s still a work in progress. I’ve been so busy that I haven’t had a chance to finish it off. I always carry a notepad and pen around with me and anytime I come up with a line or hear something, I write it down. What genre of music are we talking? It’s a mixture of Time After Time, The Scientist, and Midnight in Chelsea. It’s not really a pop song, but not really a ballad either. It’s kind of in between. It’s not a [Warne starts beatboxing a heavy dance beat] song. It’s meant to be an emotional song. Will you perform it? Ha! No! I’m writing it for some of my friends, see what they think of it and then if anyone wants to use it they can. Otherwise, it’s just my own fun exercise to say I wrote a song. What did you make of Shane Warne: The Musical? It was quite interesting to see your life flash before your eyes. But I don’t think anyone should have the right to do something on your life without your permission. I did go up on the stage and say well done, because it was interesting. But it didn’t have my endorsement. What is the single biggest amount of money you’ve lost in a hand of poker? Too much. Too much to say? [Stubbornly this time] Too much. OK then! Can you tell Small Talk a joke? No, but I can give you a tip: never eat yellow snow. Thanks Shane. Bye! Bye Small Talk!
